awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation Research Grant: Reducing Stereotype Threat by enhancing emotional regulation: A role for Mindful Awareness Practice for STEM majors
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Knowledge is an academic intervention for first year students with an interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields created at Virginia State University.  As a result of this award, we have determined that affective factors may play just as important role in STEM acheivement than remediation and tutoring when provided early in the college career. Our findings further indicated that the critical period for commencing an intervention are during the first 3 semesters of college.   Incoming students who come from under-resourced highschools may particularly benefi from a summer bridge program where study skills are taught and practicted and then reinforced during the school year.

Our findings showed that activities that targeted skills, beliefs and attitdues resulted in a decreas in self- handicapping and an increase in self-regulation. These proximal goals were associated with more distal goals of higher overall GPA; increased persistence in the STEM major and retention to the fourth semester.

The major activities that we believe contributed most to these results were:
1.  Providing incoming students with basic academic skill training. We call this the "Project Knowledge 10 Top Tips for Academic Success." Habits were introduced to students during a one-week summer bridge that occurred one week before freshmen orientation. Utilization of the habits were monitored at weekly meetings during the fall and spring semesters.
2.  Providing  a trained and effective upperclass mentor and providing weekly meetings and other activities to encourage and sustain the relationships. Students were introduced to their mentors during the summer bridge program. Each mentor had no more than 5 mentees. Data from weekly check-ins were collected and informal meetings were encouraged.  Our qualitative research also found that the more effective mentors were more introspecitve and scored higher on self-regulation and emotional intelligence scales.
3. .Encourage introspection in mentors and mentees in order to establish mental habits conducive to the mitigation of self-handicapping. We did this by providing training in metacognitive skills, such as guided imagery meditation, focused breathing, and introspective activities such as  "discovering your why" exercises

These three areas of focus allowed for the transfer of academic values within a relational bond. The training in academic skills and habits, while necessary was not sufficient in protecting a student's emerging academic identity from real threats, such as difficult classwork or inital bad grades.  Verticle mentoring proved to be a successful mechanism of value transfer, provided that the mentor-mentee relationship was established early and then supported over time.. The program further encouraged allighnent of a student's behaviors and actions with their inner beliefs and attitudes about academic achievement.

Previous NSF-supported research at our institution had found that African American students were more likely to utilize self-handicapping as a component of goal-orientation. Self-handicapping is one type of coping mechanism that may serve as an effective ego-protective device but may interfeere with a student's stated academic or career goals. Therefore, training in emotional regulation and goal setting were important componenets in this intervention. These findings are particularly relevant to programs aimed at increasing  enrollment and retention in the number of under-represented minorities in STEM.

In combination, these findings lend support to validating the Phenomenological Variant of the Ecological Systems Theory (PVEST). PVEST provides a more holistic framework to examine academic achievement in African American students by focusing on affective factors related to resilience.  Previously unidentified affective factors were shown to exert specific and malleable influences on academic behavior in African American freshmen students. Furthermore, effective intervention strategies were employed that led to measureable increases in academic outcomes that persisted over time. In terms of intellectual merit, additional study is needed in order to confirm the fitness of the structured equation model and to identify latent or unmeasured factors that may also be influencing academic behavior.

Modified by: Cheryl P Talley
